docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 4 EXAMINATION IN CHIEF AND RE-EXAMINATION [ss 37–39]

heading.title: DIVISION 4 EXAMINATION IN CHIEF AND RE-EXAMINATION [ss 37–39]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 4 EXAMINATION IN CHIEF AND RE-EXAMINATION [ss 37–39]

p.text: A leading question must not be put to a witness in examination in chief or in re-examination unless:
the court gives leave, or
the question relates to a matter introductory to the witness's evidence, or

no objection is made to the question and (leaving aside the party conducting the examination in chief or re-examination) each other party to the proceeding is represented by an Australian legal practitioner, legal counsel or prosecutor, or
the question relates to a matter that is not in dispute, or

if the witness has specialised knowledge based on the witness's training, study or experience — the question is asked for the purpose of obtaining the witness's opinion about a hypothetical statement of facts, being facts in respect of which evidence has been, or is intended to be, given.
[subs (1) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[11], effective 1 January 2009]

Unless the court otherwise directs, subsection (1) does not apply in civil proceedings to a question that relates to an investigation, inspection or report that the witness made in the course of carrying out public or official duties.
Subsection (1) does not prevent a court from exercising power under rules of court to allow a written statement or report to be tendered or treated as evidence in chief of its maker.
“Leading question” is defined in the Dictionary.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 292–293, 618–620
ALRC 38 para 113(a)
The following terms are defined in the Dictionary : examination in chief, re-examination and lawyer.

A “leading question” is defined in the Dictionary as one that either suggests the answer or assumes the existence of a matter that has not been the subject of evidence: see also R v Eade (2002) 131 A Crim R 390; [2002] NSWCCA 257; BC200203528 . The definition substantially accords with the common law position: GPI Leisure Corp Ltd v Herdsman Investments Pty Ltd (No 3) (1990) 20 NSWLR 15 at 25 . The section attempts to provide a list of the circumstances where the prohibition on the use of leading questions will not apply. Generally these circumstances are the same as the position that applied under the common law: see [29.5.75] .

Leading questions are permissible where the question relates to an investigation, inspection or report that the witness made in the course of carrying out public or official duties. See the notes at [29.5.75] .

level.toc-caption: [50,300.25] Rules of court relating to witness statements

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,300.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.4.

heading.title: Rules of court relating to witness statements

p.text: The rules provide for the use of written statements in the Commercial Division: Practice Note 39; in the Construction List: Practice Note 58. There is power in r 31.4 for the court to direct the use of witness statements in any proceedings. See the notes at [31.4.5] .
A party who called a witness may, with the leave of the court, question the witness, as though the party were cross-examining the witness, about:
evidence given by the witness that is unfavourable to the party, or

a matter of which the witness may reasonably be supposed to have knowledge and about which it appears to the court the witness is not, in examination in chief, making a genuine attempt to give evidence, or
whether the witness has, at any time, made a prior inconsistent statement.
The party questioning the witness under this section may, with the leave of the court, question the witness about matters relevant only to the witness's credibility.
The rules about admissibility of evidence relevant only to credibility are set out in Part 3.7 .
Questioning under this section is to take place before the other parties cross-examine the witness, unless the court otherwise directs.
If the court so directs, the order in which the parties question the witness is to be as the court directs.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account in determining whether to give leave or a direction under this section, it is to take into account:
whether the party gave notice at the earliest opportunity of his or her intention to seek leave, and
the matters on which, and the extent to which, the witness has been, or is likely to be, questioned by another party.
A party is subject to the same liability to be cross-examined under this section as any other witness if:
a proceeding is being conducted in the name of the party by or on behalf of an insurer or other person, and
the party is a witness in the proceeding.
ALRC 38 paras 113(b), 114
The following terms are defined in the Dictionary : cross-examination, credibility and witness.
Legislation cited in [50,305.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

At common law (and under previous statutory provisions such as of the Evidence Act 1898 s 53 (repealed): Greenough v Eccles (1859) 5 CBNS 786 at 806; 141 ER 315 at 323 ) the entitlement of a party to cross-examine its own witness depended upon the witness being shown to be “hostile”. A witness was “hostile” in the relevant sense if they were “unwilling, to tell the truth and the whole truth in answer to non leading questions”: see R v Hayden [1959] VR 102; [1959] ALR 332 . Accordingly, at common law, it was not sufficient to show that the evidence of the witness in question was merely “unfavourable”: see Cariboo Observer Ltd v Carson Truck Lines Ltd (1962) 32 DLR 2d 36; Wells v South Australian Railways Commissioner (1973) 5 SASR 74 .

The present section confers a wider discretion to permit cross-examination and that discretion does depend on a party being unexpectedly confronted by an adverse witness: R v Fowler [2000] NSWCCA 142; BC200002699 ; R v Parkes (2003) 147 A Crim R 450; [2003] NSWCCA 12; BC200300319 ; R v Petroulias (No 29) [2007] NSWSC 1005; BC200711483 ; Razzak v R [2008] NSWCCA 304; BC200811197 . It permits a party to cross-examine its own witness (with the leave of the court) where the evidence is merely unfavourable (see [50,305.25] below), where the witness is merely uncooperative and where the witness has made a prior inconsistent statement.

The permissible scope of the examination is limited to questioning “about” the three matters described in s 38(1)(a)–(c) — namely, unfavourable, disingenuous and inconsistent evidence. But it is not confined to questioning specifically directed to one or more of those three matters. It includes questioning directed to establishing either the probability of the factual state of affairs contended for by the party conducting the questioning, or the improbability of the witness’s evidence on that matter: see R v Le (2002) 54 NSWLR 474 at 493; 130 A Crim R 44; [2002] NSWCCA 186; BC200202750 at [90] ; R v Petroulias (No 29) [2007] NSWSC 1005; BC200711483 .

Section 38(6) sets out, but only as matters of inclusion, two matters that must be taken into account in considering the grant of leave. They are (i) whether any prior notice has been given of the application and (ii) the likely questioning by other parties. Presumably it will also be relevant to consider both the subject matter of the proposed cross-examination, the conduct of the witness and the capacity of the party to call contrary evidence: Cariboo Observer Ltd v Carson Truck Lines Ltd (1962) 32 DLR 2d 36; Wells v South Australian Railways Commissioner (1973) 5 SASR 74 . The obligation to consider the likely questioning by other parties suggests some analogy with the criterion in s 42(3) as to whether the evidence would be “better ascertained” by permitting cross-examination. However, even if that criterion is available in relation to the present section, the cross-examination is to be confined to the matters in s 38(1) unless further leave is given under s 38(3) .

In addition to the matters set out in s 38(6) , the provisions of s 192(2) (and, in an appropriate case, the discretions in ss 135 and 137 ) are relevant to the question of whether leave should be granted. It is not a necessary element for a grant of leave under the section that there be evidence of a motive or reason for the witness to give untruthful evidence: Director of Public Prosecutions v Nair (2009) 236 FLR 239; [2009] ACTCA 17; BC200910178 .

level.toc-caption: [50,305.20] No genuine attempt to give evidence

heading.title: No genuine attempt to give evidence

p.text: The section contemplates that leave may be given if the witness is not making a genuine attempt to give evidence: see Adam v R (2001) 207 CLR 96; 183 ALR 625; BC200106148 ; R v Fowler [2000] NSWCCA 142; BC200002699 ; R v Le (2002) 54 NSWLR 474; 130 A Crim R 44; [2002] NSWCCA 186; BC200202750 ; R v Crowther-Wilkinson [2003] NSWSC 226; BC200301320 . It does not require a finding that the witness is being untruthful. If a witness is being apparently untruthful, that may provide a justification for allowing cross-examination on credibility issues: see [50,305.35] .

Where a prior inconsistent statement is relied upon to justify an application to cross-examine, the inconsistency should be clear: Carbury v Measures (1904) 8 SR (NSW) 569; Price v Bevan (1974) 8 SASR 81. And it should relate directly to the issues: Alchin v Cmr for Railways (1935) 35 SR (NSW) 498 . Inconsistency is “not to be determined by splitting hairs about the form of the statement but by seeing whether it is inconsistent as a matter of common sense”: Cotton v Cmr for Road Transport and Tramways (1943) 43 SR (NSW) 66 at 71; 60 WN (NSW) 42 per Jordan CJ. Where the making of a prior inconsistent statement is relied upon it is not necessary to show that it has been made to a party or to his or her attorney nor even that the party calling the witness has done so in the firm belief that the earlier statement would be adhered to: McLellan v Bowyer (1961) 106 CLR 95; [1962] ALR 243; BC6100090 . A prior statement that is in the form of an expression of opinion may nevertheless qualify as a prior inconsistent statement if it impliedly contains an assertion of fact that is contrary to the witness's evidence.
Legislation cited in [50,305.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 38(1), s 38(6).

Although s 38(6) refers to prior notice as a consideration relevant to the grant of leave under this section, the permissible grounds of cross-examination set out in s 38(1) suggest that there will be very limited opportunities for prior notice. (Because each of the stated grounds could only be made out after the witness had given some evidence in the proceedings.) It may be that a party could give conditional notice, ie, notice that an application will be made if any of the grounds are made out when the witness gives evidence.
Legislation cited in [50,305.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 38(1), s 38(3).

Although the section permits cross-examination in circumstances wider than would have previously justified a finding that the witness was hostile, the cross-examination cannot deal with credibility issues unless further leave is given under s 38(3) . In the exercise of that discretion (as well as perhaps the grant of leave under s 38(1) ) it may be relevant to consider the principles relating to hostile witnesses. (A witness who was declared hostile was liable to be cross-examined generally on credit: R v Hunter [1956] VLR 31; [1955] ALR 786 ; Price v Bevan (1974) 8 SASR 81. A hostile witness is one who “bears a hostile animus to the party calling him and so does not give his evidence fairly and with the desire to tell the truth to the court; he is not adverse in the statutory sense when his testimony merely contradicts his proof or because he is unfavourable to the party calling him”: Phipson on Evidence, 12th ed, Sweet & Maxwell, London, 1976, para 1576. In R v Hayden [1959] VR 102; [1959] ALR 332 Sholl J said that a witness was “adverse” in the relevant sense (that is hostile) if he was “unwilling, if called by a party who cannot ask him leading questions, to tell the truth and the whole truth in answer to non-leading questions”. The hostility of a witness may be demonstrated by demeanour in the witness box: R v Murphy (1837) 8 C & P 297; 173 ER 502; Price v Manning (1889) 42 Ch D 372 ; Coles v Coles (1866) LR 1 PD 70. The existence of a prior inconsistent statement may be sufficient to indicate hostility: McLellan v Bowyer (1961) 106 CLR 95; [1962] ALR 243 ; R v Fraser (1956) 40 Cr App R 160; R v Harris (1927) 20 Cr App R 144; R v James [1954] Crim LR 55; R v Caracella [1958] VR 382 . Whether a witness is in fact hostile is to be determined objectively. The mere fact that a witness is the other party does not, on its own, indicate hostility: Price v Manning (1889) 42 Ch D 372 . Neither does a witness's desire that the opposing party should succeed: R v Hayden [1959] VR 102 at 103; [1959] ALR 332 ; R v Ball (1839) 8 CP 745; 137 ER 699. A witness who is merely forgetful is not hostile: R v Manning [1968] Crim LR 675.

As indicated in [50,305.15] the considerations potentially relevant to a determination that the witness is "unfavourable" are not defined. The word “unfavourable” as used in s 38(1)(a) means “not favourable” as opposed to “adverse” (in the sense of being hostile): see R v Souleyman (1996) 40 NSWLR 712 at 715; BC9603373 ; R v Lozano (NSWCCA, 60487 of 1996, 10 June 1997, unreported, BC9702441); R v Ronen [2004] NSWSC 1298; BC200409614 . Accordingly, where a witness makes a statement but does not come up to proof in that statement in significant respects, the evidence may be regarded as “unfavourable” within the meaning of that term as it is used in the section: see R v Souleyman, above; R v Kneebone (1999) 47 NSWLR 450; [1999] NSWCCA 279; BC9906003 ; R v Glasby (2000) 115 A Crim R 465; [2000] NSWCCA 83; BC200003417 ; R v Taylor [2003] NSWCCA 194; BC200306670 . But a witness whose evidence is merely equivocal is not relevantly “unfavourable” for the purposes of the section: Klewer v Walton [2003] NSWCA 308; BC200306051 at [20] per Hodgson JA.

A determination under s 38 is regarded as a matter for the discretion of the trial judge and is therefore treated as a matter of practice and procedure. Accordingly, the refusal by a trial judge to allow the cross-examination of a witness pursuant to s 38 is not a “ruling on the admissibility of evidence” within the meaning of s 5F(3A) of the Criminal Appeal Act 1912: see R v Milakovic [2004] NSWCCA 199; BC200403885 . In the exercise of the discretion, the trial judge must have regard to the provisions of s 192(2) of the Act (see R v Hogan [2001] NSWCCA 292; BC200104439 ; Stanoevski v R (2001) 202 CLR 115; 177 ALR 285; [2001] HCA 4; BC200100150 ; R v Stevens [2001] NSWCCA 330; BC200108490 ; R v Le (2002) 54 NSWLR 474; 130 A Crim R 44; [2002] NSWCCA 186; BC200202750 . It can be expected that the determination will not lightly be interfered with: McLellan v Bowyer (1961) 106 CLR 95; [1962] ALR 243 ; R v See Lun (1932) 32 SR (NSW) 363; 49 WN (NSW) 116 not following Harris v Minister for Public Works (1912) 12 SR (NSW) 149; 29 WN (NSW) 33 ; contrast Wentworth v Rogers (No 10) (1987) 8 NSWLR 398 at 407 (failure to find hostility overturned on appeal). Evidence relevant to the issue of hostility should be taken on the voir dire: R v Thompson [1917] 2 KB 630; R v Hunter [1956] VLR 31; [1955] ALR 786 at 790 ; R v Caracella [1958] VR 382 ; Price v Bevan (1974) 8 SASR 81 at 96.
Legislation cited in [50,305.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Subsection (7).
(NSW) Evidence Act 1898 s 53.

Subsection (7) applies where a person (usually an insurer) has assumed the conduct of proceedings in the place of a named party. It ensures that the named party, whose interest has been assumed by the insurer, is liable to cross-examination in the same way as any other witness in the proceedings. The provision overcomes the contrary view taken in Vocisano v Vocisano (1974) 130 CLR 267; 3 ALR 97; BC7400023 in relation to s 53 of the Evidence Act 1898.
Legislation cited in [50,305.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 38(2), s 38(4), (5).
Section 38(2) ensures that the party granted leave under this rule will retain a right to re-examine subject to any directions that the court may give under s 38(4) and (5) .
On re-examination:
a witness may be questioned about matters arising out of evidence given by the witness in cross-examination, and
other questions may not be put to the witness unless the court gives leave.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 628–629
ALRC 38 paras 117–118

The section reflects the common law position that re-examination must be confined to matters that arise out of cross-examination. The section confines permissible re-examination questions to matters "arising out of the evidence given by the witness in cross-examination".
That expression justifies the following propositions in relation to the permissible scope of re-examination:

Material that is clearly new can only be adduced with leave: see generally Wodjcic v Incorporated Nominal Defendant [1969] VR 323 ; R v Szach (1980) 23 SASR 504; 2 A Crim R 321 . The section does not make any provision for further cross-examination in the event that leave is granted under s 39(b). However in practice, such a course is generally allowed and is often a condition upon which leave is granted.

Where the cross-examination of a witness involves no more than confirmation or repetition of something addressed in their evidence-in-chief (or in the evidence of another witness for the same party) and does not involve any material alteration to that evidence, the statutory language does not permit re-examination to clarify, amplify or challenge that matter: Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) v Rich [2005] NSWSC 1015; BC200507648 .
Re-examination is permissible in relation to ambiguities and uncertainties that had arisen in the course of cross-examination.

Re-examination is permissible in order to explain or supplement evidence that, if uncorrected, would be potentially misleading or incomplete: R v Lavery (No 2) (1979) 20 SASR 430 ; R v Clune (No 1) [1975] VR 723 at 734; and see also [29.5.105]. The correction of ambiguities is one of the most obvious examples where re-examination is permissible. But the permissible scope of re-examination extends to include evidence in relation to any cross-examination evidence that would, unless supplemented or explained, leave the court with factual impressions (whether directly related to issues or credibility) that are capable of being construed unfavourably to the party calling the witness and would represent a distortion or an incomplete account of the truth as the witness is able to present it: Roach v Page (No 2) [2003] NSWSC 772; BC200305949 (evidence in re-examination about inferences to be drawn about past reasons and motives in relation to the sale of properties).
Legislation cited in [50,310.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 192, s 39(b).

The section does not make express provision for further cross-examination if leave is granted under s 39(b) . In practice however, this will generally be a condition of the grant of leave. Section 192 of the Act specifically allows the court to impose terms on the grant of any leave.
